title: In English, can I say 'There are still many people who retain their former morals, even and especially in these large cities'? - Quora

response.answer_text: There is nothing so wrong with your sentence, but your word choice could be better. For instance, “formal morals” sounds quite strange. What other kind of morals are there? Are there “informal morals?” If so, what would they be? So, what you want to say is not clear. Perhaps you want to say that many people keep their faith no matter where they live. The word, retain, has a slightly different meaning, as though to say these people are just holding on despite others’ lack of morals, as though they are in a struggle. Maybe you are not referring to religious faith, but morality in general. Morality would be a better word than “formal morals.” Morality encompasses a sense of right and wrong no matter the grounds of that awareness. Conscience has a similar meaning. Hopefully, I have given you enough words here for to choose which works best for conveying your meaning.

I have to wonder if you mean “former” morals, instead of formal. The sentence doesn’t make a heck of a lot of sense as you’ve written it. And the sentence seems a bit stilted. Try: Many still hold on to the morals they grew up with, even when they move to large cities.
